awd_titl_txt: CAS: Harvesting Electrons From Lower Energy Excited States to Extend Spectral Coverage and Facilitate Multiple Charge Collection Following Singlet Fission on Metal Oxides
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemical Structure, Dynamics & Mechanisms-B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professors Blank and Gladfelter from the University of Minnesota-Twin Cities and Professor Pappenfus from the University of Minnesota-Morris seek to build a more thorough understanding of how light can be used to induce separation of charge, a critical first step in the conversion solar energy into electrical or chemical energy. In addition to photovoltaic devices, light-induced charge transfer is part of other devices such as sensors. This project will focus on using well-defined nanocrystals of metal oxides as the scaffold for probing this behavior. A better understanding of how to leverage metal oxide semiconductors is expected to contribute to the  development of a range of optoelectronic devices and  to improving the efficiency of such devices. This project will directly support the training and education of the next generation of physical/physical organic chemists, including graduate students and undergraduate students, in areas of chemistry that cross the traditional disciplinary boundaries. The University of Minnesota-Morris is a rural, primarily undergraduate institution, and this project will provide undergraduate students at Morris with a collaborative research experience.

Nanocrystalline films of semiconducting metal oxides often play a central role in devices that involve the separation of charge. Commonly employed metal oxides have conduction band energies that place thermodynamic and kinetic limitations on the molecules used as sensitizers. Indium oxide has yet to receive much attention, but it has tremendous potential. With a lower energy conduction band, it opens a new window of opportunity to access lower energy sensitizer states. This window would, in principle, allow extension of the spectrum of light that can be harvested and provide access for charge transfer from lower energy triplet states of the sensitizers. The triplet states that are of particular interest in this proposal are those that are generated via singlet fission. This project will use transparent solution phase dispersions of nanocrystals with narrow size distributions as a well-defined experimental platform to investigate the excited state dynamics and charge transfer of the sensitizer. The goal is to realize, characterize and optimize charge multiplication through singlet fission on a transparent metal oxide surface with the potential to increase the efficiency of light harvesting.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
In all types of solar photovoltaic cells, the energy from the absorbed photons is used to separate charge. Metal oxides are used in these devices to carry charge and in dye sensitized solar cells to participate in the charge separation event. Their bandgaps, however, are too large to absorb visible light, so they require a sensitizer, which is commonly a coordination compound or an organic dye that absorbs in the visible region and transfers charge from the dye excited state to the metal oxide. Understanding the details of the excited state charge separation event is the focus of this research. We chose to study this event on well-defined nanocrystals (NC) of zinc oxide and indium oxide. The interest in indium oxide stems from its lower energy conduction band that opens a new window of opportunity to access lower energy sensitizer states. This window allows extension of the spectrum of light that can be harvested and provide access to lower energy triplet excited states. The triplet states that are of particular interest in this proposal are those that are generated via singlet fission (SF).

Intellectual Merit:

We synthesized a new dye bearing a perylene dimide chromophore that has a low-lying triplet excited state. Binding to the ZnO NC surface via the carboxylic acid end group was seen to promote aggregation and excimer-like state formation of PDI-COOH. Surface coverage on the NCs was altered by changing the dye : NC ratio, which in turn affected the aggregate : monomer content in the sample. Samples at very low dye : NC ratios possessed predominantly monomeric character, with the degree of aggregation increasing as the dye : NC ratio increased. This trend results from a trade-off between two factors: higher entropy associated with the larger number of accessible binding sites on NCs at low dye : NC ratios, and π-π interactions that favor aggregates over monomers on the ZnO NC surface at high ratios. Our results suggest that a small number of aggregates and excimer-like states exist even at very low PDI-COOH: ZnO NC ratios, indicating that modulating the surface coverage alone while effective in controlling the degree of aggregation, may not be sufficient to eliminate it completely. Additional approaches, such as synthetic modification of the dye structure, might be required to achieve complete control over aggregation.

 Excited state electron transfer into oleate-capped indium oxide NCs was studied using dyes 1 and 2 that were synthesized in our laboratory. Pump-probe experiments of 1 and 2 on In2O3 NCs showed that electron transfer is ~9 times faster than on previously reported oleate-capped ZnO NCs (J. Phys. Chem. C, 2020, 124, 15565 – 15573). The results are consistent with a lower conduction band minimum, resulting in a higher density of available acceptor states, increasing the rate of electron transfer in agreement with Marcus theory. This is the first investigation of electron transfer to colloidal In2O3 NCs and suggests that In2O3 NCs can be used for quantitative studies of dye-NC electron transfer. As In2O3 has a lower conduction band than typical semiconductors such as TiO2 and ZnO, a broader range of energetically accessible dyes can be studied.

Broader Impacts:

A better understanding of how to leverage metal oxide semiconductors with lower energy conduction bands will have a broad impact on the efficiency and development of a wide range of future optoelectronic devices. This project contributed to the training and education of the next generation of physical scientists, including two graduate students and one undergraduate at the University of Minnesota Twin Cities and four undergraduates at the University of Minnesota Morris.


Last Modified: 12/23/2024
Modified by: David Blank
